resources.string: Solar system exploration
Planets
Dwarf planets
Planet X
Day 59 Earth days \n Year 88 Earth days
The smallest planet in our solar system and nearest to the Sun.
Mercury is named for the swiftest of the Roman gods.
If Earth were the size of a nickel, Mercury would be about as big as a blueberry.
Mercury has no moon.
Mercury has no rings.
Day 243 Earth days \n Year 225 Earth days
Venus is the second planet from the Sun and our closest planetary neighbor.
Venus is named for the ancient Roman goddess of love and beauty.
Venus is slightly smaller than Earth.
Venus has no moon.
Venus has no rings.
Day 23.9 hours \n Year 365.25 days
Our home planet is the third planet from the Sun.
The name Earth is a Germanic word, which simply means “the ground.”
Earth is the fifth largest planet overall.
Earth has a single moon.
Earth has no rings.
Day 24.6 hours \n Year 687 Earth days
The fourth planet from the Sun, Mars is a dusty, cold, desert world with a very thin atmosphere.
Mars was named by the Romans for their god of war because its reddish color was reminiscent of blood.
If Earth were the size of a nickel, Mars would be about as big as a raspberry.
Mars has two small moons, Phobos and Deimos.
Mars has no rings.
Day 9.92496 hours \n Year 4,333 Earth days
Jupiter is the fifth planet from our Sun and is, by far, the largest planet in the solar system.
Jupiter is named for the king of the ancient Roman gods.
If Earth were the size of a nickel, Jupiter would be about as big as a basketball.
Jupiter forms a kind of miniature solar system. Jupiter has 53 confirmed moons, as well as 14 provisional ones. Its four largest moons are Io, Europa, Ganymede and Callisto.
Its rings are composed of small, dark particles and are difficult to see except when backlit by the Sun
Day 10.7 hours \n Year 29 Earth years
Saturn is the sixth planet from the Sun and the second largest planet in our solar system. It has a dazzling system of icy rings.
The planet is named for the Roman god of agriculture and wealth.
If Earth were the size of a nickel, Saturn would be about as big as a volleyball.
Saturn has 53 confirmed moons with nine additional provisional moons.
Its rings are thought to be pieces of comets, asteroids or shattered moons that broke up before they reached the planet.
Day 17 hours 14 minutes \n Year 84 Earth years
Saturn is the seventh planet from the Sun with the third largest diameter in our solar system.
The planet is named for the Greek god of the sky.
If Earth was the size of a nickel, Uranus would be about as big as a softball.
Uranus has 27 known moons.
Uranus has two sets of rings.
Day 16 hours \n Year 165 Earth years
Neptune is the eighth and most distant planet in our solar system.
The planet is named after the Roman god of the sea.
If Earth were the size of a nickel, Neptune would be about as big as a baseball.
Neptune has 13 known moons and one provisional moon.
Neptune has five known rings.
Day 153 hours \n Year 248 Earth years
Pluto was long considered the ninth planet of our solar system.
Pluto is named after the Roman god of the underworld.
If Earth was the size of a nickel, Pluto would be about as big as a popcorn kernel.
Pluto has five known moons: Charon, Nix, Hydra, Kerberos and Styx.
Pluto has no rings.
Day 9 hours \n Year 4.6 Earth years
Dwarf planet Ceres is the largest object in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter.
Ceres is named for the Roman goddess of corn and harvests.
If Earth was the size of a nickel, Ceres would be about as big as a poppy seed.
Ceres has no moons.
Ceres does not have any rings.
Day 2.5 hours \n Year 305.34 Earth years
Along with fellow dwarf planets Pluto, Eris and Haumea, Makemake is located in the Kuiper Belt, a region outside the orbit of Neptune.
Makemake was named after the Rapanui god of fertility.
If Earth was the size of a nickel, Makemake would be about as big as a mustard seed.
Makemake has one provisional moon.
Makemake does not have any rings.
Day 4 hours \n Year 285 Earth years
Haumea resides in the Kuiper belt.
Haumea was named after the Hawaiian goddess of fertility.
If Earth was the size of a nickel, Haumea would be about as big as a sesame seed.
Haumea has two known moons: Namaka is the inner moon, and Hi\'iaka is the outer moon.
Haumea does not have any rings.
Day 25.9 hours \n Year 557 Earth years
Eris resides in the Kuiper belt.
Eris is named for the ancient Greek goddess of discord and strife.
If Earth was the size of a nickel, Eris would be about as big as a popcorn kernel.
Eris has a very small moon called Dysnomia.
Eris does not have any rings.
Planet X has not yet been discovered
The prediction is based on mathematical modeling.
A large, previously undiscovered planet may be hiding far beyond Pluto.
The gravity of this potential planet might explain the unusual orbits of those Kuiper objects.
Any object that far away from the sun will be very faint and hard to detect.
New research that provides evidence of a giant planet tracing an unusual, elongated orbit in the outer solar system.
